title: 108_hr1372
content: The Act is titled the "Broad-Based Stock Option Plan Transparency Act of 2003." Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that innovation and entrepreneurship, especially in the high technology industry, drove economic growth in the 1990s and will continue to be crucial for growth in the 21st century. Broad-based employee stock option plans help attract quality workers, incentivize innovation, and increase productivity, benefiting shareholders. Employee stock option plans that involve rank-and-file employees promote capital formation, benefit workers, improve corporate performance, and raise legitimate concerns about their impact on shareholder value. Investors deserve accurate information about employee stock option plans and their impact on shareholder value. Improved employee stock option transparency and reporting disclosures. The Securities and Exchange Commission will require companies to provide more detailed information on stock option plans and their dilutive effects in periodic reports. This includes a plain English discussion and graphic illustrations of the impact of these plans on equity interests. The Securities and Exchange Commission will require companies to provide expanded disclosure of the dilutive effect of employee stock options on earnings per share, along with prominent placement of stock option related information. Additionally, companies must include a summary of stock options granted to the top 5 executive officers. The term "equity interest" encompasses various securities and rights related to stock ownership. The Securities and Exchange Commission will evaluate transparency and reporting disclosures of employee stock option plans and submit a report to Congress. The Commission will assess the effectiveness of enhanced disclosures in increasing transparency for investors over a 3-year period. A moratorium on new accounting standards for stock options will be in place until a report is submitted to Congress. A study on the economic impact of broad-based employee stock option plans will be conducted, and a report will be submitted to Congress. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a study on employee stock option plans in high-tech industries, focusing on ownership expansion, recruitment, innovation, economic growth, and international competitiveness. A report will be submitted to Congress within a year. The Secretary will submit a report and analysis of the study on employee stock option plans in high-tech industries to specific Congressional committees within one year of the Act's enactment.
